title-group.article-title: Correlation of Small-Scale and Full-Scale Wind Tunnel Data with Flight Test Data on the Lear Jet Model 23

permissions.copyright-statement: Â© Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc., 1971

abstract.p: One of the basic questions arising from any small-scale wind tunnel test is the relationship of the low Reynolds number results to the high Reynolds number characteristics that will be encountered on the actual airplane. This paper presents a direct comparison of longitudinal lowspeed small-scale wind tunnel data, full-scale wind tunnel data, and flight test results. These data were obtained from tests on a 0.15 scale model of the Model 23 in the Wichita State University 7 X 10 ft wind tunnel, full-scale wind tunnel tests on a Model 23 in the NASA Ames 40 X 80 ft tunnel, and Lear Jet flight test results on Model 23 and Model 24 type airplanes. Since flight test data for the flaps down configuration are rather limited, most of the wind tunnel to flight comparisons are for the flaps up configuration. The results indicate good agreement between wind tunnel and flight test results for the flaps up configuration. Comparison of small-scale data with full-scale flaps down wind tunnel data shows definite areas of disagreement for identical configurations.

ref.mixed-citation: "Information for Users of the Walter H. Beech Memorial Low-Speed Wind Tunnel." Wichita State University, July 1966.
Marvin R. Barber, Fred W. Haise, and Charles K. Jones, "An Evaluation of General Aviation Aircraft Flying Qualities." Paper 660219 presented at SAE Business Aircraft Conference, Wichita, March 1966.
Marvin P. Fink and Delma C. Freeman, Jr., "Full-Scale Wind Tunnel Investigation of Static Longitudinal and Lateral Characteristics of a Light Twin-Engine Airplane." NASA TND-4983, January 1969.

Lawrence E. Putnam and Charles D. Trescot, Jr., "Effect of Aft-Fuselage-Mounted Nacelles on the Subsonic Longitu- dinal Aerodynamic Characteristics of a Twin-Turbojet Air- plane." NASA TND-3781, December 1966.
"Guide for Planning Investigations in the Ames 40 X 80 Foot Wind Tunnel." February 1967.
